original_data.question: A 63-year-old man presents to the physician with a complaint of back pain for the past 2 months. The pain is present throughout the day, and even at night when he lies down. He also complains of difficulty walking upstairs and says he recently started to wear adult diapers because he seems to have difficulty controlling his bowel movements. His vital signs are within normal limits. The neurological examination revealed bilateral lower limb weakness, diminished temperature sensation, and decreased vibratory sense. The rectal examination revealed a hard nodular mass and a weak rectal sphincter tone. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

model_response:
The presence of bilateral lower limb weakness, diminished temperature sensation, and decreased vibratory sense indicates a spinal cord lesion. The presence of a hard nodular mass and a weak rectal sphincter tone indicates a rectal/vesicle problem. The most likely cause of the symptoms is a spinal cord tumor, which is compressing both the spinal cord and the rectum. Syringomyelia is a long process, and the patient would have presented with symptoms for a long time. Herniated disc and spinal hematoma would not cause the rectal symptoms. Spinal metastasis would not cause the bilateral lower limb weakness.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Acute or chronic pain located in the posterior regions of the THORAX; LUMBOSACRAL REGION; or the adjacent regions.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Occurring or done each day.
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.

A plant genus in the family LILIACEAE generally growing in temperate areas. The word lily is also used in the common names of many plants of other genera that resemble true lilies. True lilies are erect perennial plants with leafy stems, scaly bulbs, usually narrow leaves, and solitary or clustered flowers.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Any persistent problem with walking.
A person having attained full growth or maturity. Adults are of 19 through 44 years of age. For a person between 19 and 24 years of age, YOUNG ADULT is available.
A barrier garment or padding used to absorb urine and stool, thereby helping to protect the skin and keep clothing and bedding clean.
Something not easily done, accomplished, comprehended, or solved.
The section of the alimentary canal from the STOMACH to the ANAL CANAL. It includes the LARGE INTESTINE and SMALL INTESTINE.

The act, process, or result of passing from one place or position to another. It differs from LOCOMOTION in that locomotion is restricted to the passing of the whole body from one place to another, while movement encompasses both locomotion but also a change of the position of the whole body or any of its parts. Movement may be used with reference to humans, vertebrate and invertebrate animals, and microorganisms. Differentiate also from MOTOR ACTIVITY, movement associated with behavior.
Assessment of sensory and motor responses and reflexes that is used to determine impairment of the nervous system.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
A reduction in the strength of the lower limb muscles.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
Having strength, power, or intensity less than average or expected.
A circular band of muscle that functions to regulate the size of an orifice in the body.
